clinical_study.official_title: Smartphone-Delivered Attentional Bias Modification Training for Quitting Smokers

brief_summary.textblock:
The goal of this research study is to learn if a smartphone-delivered intervention combined with nicotine replacement therapy can help you to quit smoking.
This is an investigational study. The nicotine patch used in this study is FDA approved and commercially available.
Up to 750 participants will be screened, and up to 250 eligible participants will take part in the study. All will be enrolled at MD Anderson.

detailed_description.textblock:
First Visit:
Signing this consent form does not mean that you will be able to take part in this study.
The following screening tests will be performed to help the study staff decide if you are eligible:
- You will have a brief interview during your first visit in which you will be asked about your smoking and medical history.
- Your carbon monoxide (CO -- a gas that is found in higher levels among cigarette smokers) level will be measured. For this test, you will be asked to blow air through a CO measuring device.
- You will complete a questionnaire that will ask questions about your mood. It will take about 10 minutes to complete the questionnaire.
- You will be asked to provide a urine sample to test for drug abuse. You will not be able to take part if you test positive for such drugs.
- Your urine sample will also be used to test your cotinine if the result of your CO test is below certain levels.
- If you can become pregnant, you will have a urine pregnancy test. To take part in this study, you cannot be pregnant.
- If the screening tests show that you are not eligible to take part in the study, you will not be enrolled. Other options will be discussed with you. You will only receive parking or METRO reimbursement.
If you are found to be eligible to take part in this study, the following tests and procedures will also be performed during your first visit:
- You will complete questionnaires about your smoking history and behavior. These will take about 30-45 minutes to complete.
- Urine will be collected to check your cotinine and anabasine levels. Cotinine is a chemical that measures the amount of cigarette by-products in your body. Anabasine is a chemical that helps the study staff tell if you are using tobacco or nicotine replacement therapy (NRT).
- You will have an electroencephalography (EEG) lab session. During the lab session, you will perform a task that is designed to measure your attention and emotions. This will involve looking at groups of pictures of abstract art, words, and screens with different colors as well as pictures with smoking images. During the visit, your brain electrical activity will be measured with an EEG. To do this, a net-like cap will be placed over your scalp. These tasks will take about 60 minutes to complete.
Smartphone Use:
You will be randomly assigned (as in the flip of a coin) to 1 of 2 study groups:
- If you are in Group 1, you will receive attentional bias modification (ABM) training through a smartphone. This type of training is designed to help you quit smoking.
- If you are in Group 2, you will receive "sham" training. This program looks like ABM training, but is not actually designed to help you.
You will not know which type of training you are receiving.
After the lab session on Day 1, you will be provided with a smartphone to use while you are on study. You will be trained on how to use the smartphone and smartphone application that will help you prepare to quit smoking. This training will take about 20 minutes to complete.
On Days 2-14, you will complete a training program while at home through the smartphone and application provided. Each of the daily training sessions will take about 30 minutes. After the training portion has been completed, you will answer questions about your smoking on a daily basis. These questions will take about 10 minutes to complete each day.
Study Visits:
During Visit 2 (Day 15):
- Your CO level will be measured.
- You will complete the questionnaires about your smoking history and smoking behavior.
- A urine sample will be collected to check your cotinine and anabasine levels.
- You will have another EEG lab session.
- You will be given the first half of an 8-week supply of nicotine replacement therapy or "the patch" and you will track your patch use in your smoking diary.
- You will meet with a counselor for counseling on quitting smoking. This counseling session will last about 30 minutes.
- You will return the smartphone.
Your smoking "quit date" will be scheduled for the day after your visit 2, although you are free to reduce or quit smoking before this visit if you choose to do so.
Your study counselor will contact you every two weeks (Days 29, 43, and 57) for 3 telephone counseling sessions that will last about 15 minutes each.
During Visit 3 (Day 72):
- Your CO level will be measured.
- You will complete the questionnaires about your smoking history and smoking behavior.
- A urine sample will be collected to check your cotinine and anabasine levels
- You will have another EEG lab session.
- You will return unused nicotine patches to the study staff
Length of Study:
You will be on study for about 10 weeks. Your participation in the study will be over after Visit 3.

primary_outcome.measure: Reduction of Smoking Cues and Behavior Using Smartphone-Delivered Attentional Bias Modification (ABM)
primary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline, 1 day post-training, and 8 weeks post-training
primary_outcome.description: Outcome evaluated using mixed between-within repeated measures ANOVA. The overall model assesses the impact of ABM training on short- and long-term AB, as measured in the 3 laboratory sessions by including training (ABM vs. sham) as a between-subjects variable, laboratory session (baseline, 1-day post-training, 8-weeks post-training) as a within-subjects variable, and their interaction term. The number of in-home training sessions completed and accuracy rates will be included as covariates in all models.

arm_group.description: Participants complete 13 days of Attentional Bias Modification (ABM) training through a smartphone, designed to help in smoking cessation after first lab session. Participants attend 3 lab sessions consisting of questionnaire completion, event-related potential (ERP) electroencephalography (EEG), & urine collection. Counseling sessions held in person on day 15, then on phone on days 28, 42, and 56. An 8-week supply of Nicotine replacement therapy given on day 15.

intervention.description: ABM Group: Participants complete 13 days of attentional bias modification (ABM) training through a smartphone, designed to help in smoking cessation after first lab session. Sham Group: Participants complete 13 days of smartphone training after first lab session.
Questionnaire completion regarding smoking history and behavior completed at baseline, Day 15, Day 70, and daily after Smartphone training.
Urine collected at baseline, Day 15, and at Day 72 to check cotinine levels.
Event-related potential (ERP) electroencephalography (EEG) performed at baseline, Day 15, and on Day 70.
Nicotine Replacement Therapy given to participants on Day 15 consisting of 4 weeks of 21 mg, 2 weeks of 14 mg, and 2 weeks of 7 mg.
Participants attend counseling sessions on Day 15 in person, and on the phone on Days 28, 42, and 56.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Between the ages of 18 and 65
2. Smoke an average of 5 or more cigarettes or little cigars per day (CPD) prior to telephone screen.
3. Produce an expired carbon monoxide (CO) level greater than or equal to 6 parts per million (ppm) or a NicAlert reading of >2
4. Have a working telephone
5. Interested in quitting smoking in the next 30 days
6. Fluency in spoken and written English
7. Must sign the picture consent form
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Taking psychotropic, anticonvulsive, or narcotic medication
2. Meet criteria for a current major depressive episode or suicidality
3. Have a history of neurological illness or closed head injury
4. Report uncorrected vision problems
5. Involved in current smoking cessation activity
6. Testing positive on a urine drug screen for drugs of abuse/potential abuse
7. Women who are pregnant or breastfeeding
8. Considered by the investigator to be an unsuitable or unstable candidate (e.g., due to cognitive impairment)
9. Shares the same address as a currently enrolled participant
10. Unwilling to alter or remove hairstyle, hair extensions, or wig during the clinic visits to allow for correct EEG sensor placement
11. Reports diagnosis of seizure disorder
12. Unwilling to use NRT patches
